channel.title: Rsps
channel.description: I'm fairly new to RSPS and I know how to do a bit of stuff, but which revision should I start on if I'm new? What should be my first goals on achieving? Thanks :3

item.title: Rsps
item.dc:creator: @xxxtilllyxxx xxxtilllyxxx
item.description:
@xxxtilllyxxx wrote:

[quote=“arham 4, post:31, topic:542366”][quote author=Fabrice L link=topic=661244.msg4425395#msg4425395 date=1400607959]

So out of 520201 registered members, you’re saying that more than a select few of them are able to do so? I highly doubt that. Only a select few of the registered members can do anything, and by select few, I’m talking less than a few hundred.

so by “select few” you really mean anyone who isn’t new or retarded

I guess that select few are all the people who can create a server without using PI
[/quote]
Lmao, way to sum it up[/quote]

Lmfaooo basically ^

Read full topic

item.title: Rsps
item.dc:creator: @xx_matty_xx Justin Bieber
item.description:
@xx_matty_xx wrote:

[quote=“xxxtilllyxxx, post:24, topic:542366”]I know blakeman does, but either way. Only a select few actually learn the language to the point where they can make their own applications[/quote]Yeah, it’s not really a “select few” lol. You probably didn’t even know me before I posted in here.

Read full topic

item.title: Rsps
item.dc:creator: @Clawz_fury lare69
item.description:
@Clawz_fury wrote:

xxxtilllyxxx:

I know blakeman does, but either way. Only a select few actually learn the language to the point where they can make their own applications

What are you even talking about…? Only a select few? I make my own applications in Java all the time and I’m at a pretty average level. Runescape private servers taught me the fundamental building blocks of object orientation, and I didn’t even start reading up on Java until I started learning about concurrency.

Read full topic

item.description:

[quote=“jme, post:21, topic:542366”][quote author=xxxtilllyxxx link=topic=661244.msg4425190#msg4425190 date=1400520160]
How many successful programmers have become successful learning off nothing but RSPS?
[/quote]
Not sure about RSPS, but runescape cheating collected many good programmers. (Edit: well it wasn’t exclusively rs cheating I suppose)

And willing to bet some owe their careers to it.[/quote]

I do.

Read full topic

item.title: Rsps
item.dc:creator: @xx_matty_xx Justin Bieber
item.description:
@xx_matty_xx wrote:

[quote=“xxxtilllyxxx, post:19, topic:542366”]Yes, but not everybody is you, just look at all of the little kids downloading private servers, changing the name, and hosting them as their own. You are taught almost nothing. You copy a few tutorials, and you have your own server. You learn almost nothing. Some people are an exception, like you and me, Arham, etc. We actually learned things, and are able to use our knowledge outside of private servers, but most of the people here don’t know very much about the language at all.[/quote]I dunno, I was one of those little kids “begging for da code”. I tried learning Java properly but just couldn’t apply it to anything I wanted to do, and as a kid there’s no way I would have considered reading tutorials or books unless they were written in context of something fun and practical. The only intro Java books I know cover basic OO and simple programming. Not many kids want to write programs to calculate the area of a circle, or construct object-oriented banking models. It’s very easy to look back and say “Oh I would have started by learning assembly and using it to write my own C compiler as it would give me solid computer science foundations”, but you forget just how hard it was back then.

Read full topic

item.title: Rsps
item.dc:creator: @xxxtilllyxxx xxxtilllyxxx
item.description:
@xxxtilllyxxx wrote:

Yes, but not everybody is you, just look at all of the little kids downloading private servers, changing the name, and hosting them as their own. You are taught almost nothing. You copy a few tutorials, and you have your own server. You learn almost nothing. Some people are an exception, like you and me, Arham, etc. We actually learned things, and are able to use our knowledge outside of private servers, but most of the people here don’t know very much about the language at all.

Read full topic

item.title: Rsps
item.dc:creator: @xx_matty_xx Justin Bieber
item.description:
@xx_matty_xx wrote:

xxxtilllyxxx:

Yes, but if you’re drafted into the workforce, they’ll already expect you to know how to use javac, notepad, syntax highlighters, etc. Not every environment has an IDE available.

Indeed, but it’s not an issue for anyone lower than a category 3 moron. I don’t know where you’ve been working, but where I’ve worked they don’t give you a hard time because of a gap in your knowledge. As long as you find out and don’t take forever it’s not a big deal. You can’t be expected to know everything.

xxxtilllyxxx:

Also, learning Java is a very hard and lengthy thing to do.

Yep, but there’s nothing wrong with giving it a little more context. When I started to learn programming I didn’t want to learn about chars and ints, I wanted to make games. Maybe that was just because I was a kid. RSPS provided me with a gateway into the programming paradigm and allowed me to excel as an experienced level 8 Java developer. Obviously if you’re 25 then no, stop messing around with silly private servers and go read some real Java tutorials because you’re a grown man for goodness sake.

xxxtilllyxxx:

You’ll never become good at it solely from working on one single project.

Yep, that’s what I said.

xxxtilllyxxx:

You’re better off to make your own small programs, and learn off there. Following documentation from the Java docs and learning as you go. Downloading a PI, and changing variables causes false hope for failed programmers.

Yeah, that works. Again, depends how old you are and what aims you have… I enjoyed my RSPS-introduction to Java and it didn’t harm me or cause any false hope.

Read full topic

item.title: Rsps
item.dc:creator: @xxxtilllyxxx xxxtilllyxxx
item.description:
@xxxtilllyxxx wrote:

[quote=“Justin Bieber, post:16, topic:542366”]I’m not trying to be a dick, but that’s just not true. Sure, if you learn Java solely from RSPS then you’ll suck. If you learn Java from any single project, you’ll still suck. All I’m saying is that starting out with RSPS shouldn’t cause problems later on, and if it does then you probably weren’t destined to do very well as a programmer anyway.

The IDE thing is also a non-issue. When I learned Java we all started out using IDEs. A year later we had to use javac from the command line. The people who had never used the command line before shit bricks, but quickly realised that it’s not actually that much different from using the IDE and there’s lots of lovely documentation out there to help them through it.[/quote]

Yes, but if you’re drafted into the workforce, they’ll already expect you to know how to use javac, notepad, syntax highlighters, etc. Not every environment has an IDE available. Also, learning Java is a very hard and lengthy thing to do. You’ll never become good at it solely from working on one single project. You’re better off to make your own small programs, and learn off there. Following documentation from the Java docs and learning as you go. Downloading a PI, and changing variables causes false hope for failed programmers.

Read full topic

item.title: Rsps
item.dc:creator: @xx_matty_xx Justin Bieber
item.description:
@xx_matty_xx wrote:

I’m not trying to be a dick, but that’s just not true. Sure, if you learn Java solely from RSPS then you’ll suck. If you learn Java from any single project, you’ll still suck. All I’m saying is that starting out with RSPS shouldn’t cause problems later on, and if it does then you probably weren’t destined to do very well as a programmer anyway.

The IDE thing is also a non-issue. When I learned Java we all started out using IDEs. A year later we had to use javac from the command line. The people who had never used the command line before shit bricks, but quickly realised that it’s not actually that much different from using the IDE and there’s lots of lovely documentation out there to help them through it.

Read full topic

item.title: Rsps
item.dc:creator: @xxxtilllyxxx xxxtilllyxxx
item.description:
@xxxtilllyxxx wrote:

Justin Bieber:

That isn’t what I said? I said that learning to code through RSPS isn’t going to ingrain these terrible habits into your brain. If someone would like to learn programming by messing around with a game that they enjoy then that’s fine. I’d rather do that than read some fuc boring java documentation.

I was more-or-less targeted towards your negative “Unless you’re a class 3 moron it’ll take you no time at all to “unlearn” any of these bad habits.”

To be honest, you might have more fun learning with RSPS, but once you jump into a real life application environment, you’re completely fucked. Just like those people who are IDE dependant, and can’t use anything but eclipse. If you don’t want to pursue Java is a potential future, RSPS is a great place to have fun, but if you want to take Java seriously, learn it seriously.

Read full topic

item.title: Rsps
item.dc:creator: @xx_matty_xx Justin Bieber
item.description:
@xx_matty_xx wrote:

That isn’t what I said? I said that learning to code through RSPS isn’t going to ingrain these terrible habits into your brain. If someone would like to learn programming by messing around with a game that they enjoy then that’s fine. I’d rather do that than read some fuc boring java documentation.

Read full topic

item.title: Rsps
item.dc:creator: @xxxtilllyxxx xxxtilllyxxx
item.description:
@xxxtilllyxxx wrote:

[quote=“Justin Bieber, post:11, topic:542366”][quote author=xxxtilllyxxx link=topic=661244.msg4425123#msg4425123 date=1400482039]
Learn the language before learning bad programming habits taught my 13 year olds who think they are “procoders” (no offence to the gifted 13 year olds cough arham *cough). Please learn Java first. You’ll be stuck in a vicious cycle of shitty programming habits.
[/quote][quote author=John link=topic=661244.msg4422639#msg4422639 date=1399200053]
The most documented revision is 317, and more people here are readily available to help with issues concerning it as opposed to other revisions. If you’re just starting out I’d recommend studying the Java language, and then moving on to find a base you like and going from there.
Pro tip: don’t attempt to learn Java through RSPS. In most cases you’ll pick up bad habits and only use them again instead of improving.
[/quote]
Unless you’re a class 3 moron it’ll take you no time at all to “unlearn” any of these bad habits. If understanding the faults in the RSPS code you did when you were 12 is too much for you then you’re not going to be able to adapt to new programming rules, standards and design patterns.[/quote]

How many successful programmers have become successful learning off nothing but RSPS?

Read full topic

item.title: Rsps
item.dc:creator: @Elrick Elrick
item.description:
@Elrick wrote:

IMO, the best revision is any right before the EoC update. The last time I had played RS, people quit or went to OSRS because of the EoC update.

Read full topic

item.title: Rsps
item.dc:creator: @arham_4 arham 4
item.description:
@arham_4 wrote:

[quote=“naseem142, post:3, topic:542366”][quote author=Fabrice L link=topic=661244.msg4420121#msg4420121 date=1398019635]
3. Revision: just choose what revision you like most and try to get as many people you can to like it as much
[/quote]

Not really , as there are different amount of people who love each revision so you should go with a revision that most people would love to play, For example if you choose an EoC revision, not much people like it therefore you wouldn’t attract as much player as you could have on another revision, But thought it depends, If you create amazing content then you might get a good amount of players, Who knows…[/quote]
317s are the most documented, so I’d go with that.

Read full topic

item.title: Rsps
item.dc:creator: @Flame3 John
item.description:
@Flame3 wrote:

The most documented revision is 317, and more people here are readily available to help with issues concerning it as opposed to other revisions. If you’re just starting out I’d recommend studying the Java language, and then moving on to find a base you like and going from there.
Pro tip: don’t attempt to learn Java through RSPS. In most cases you’ll pick up bad habits and only use them again instead of improving.

Read full topic
